factoid: Hélène said "You absolutely must come and see me."
Hélène said this in a tone that implied that this was absolutely necessary for certain considerations he could not know of.
Hélène said that on Tuesday between eight and nine she would see Borís.
Hélène said that seeing Borís would give her great pleasure.
Borís promised to fulfill Hélène's wish.
Borís was about to begin a conversation with Hélène.
Anna Pávlovna called Borís away.
Anna Pávlovna used the pretext that her aunt wished to hear him.
Anna Pávlovna said "You know her husband, of course?"
Anna Pávlovna indicated Hélène with a sorrowful gesture.
Anna Pávlovna said Hélène is an unfortunate and charming woman.
Anna Pávlovna told someone not to mention Hélène's husband before her.
Anna Pávlovna said it is too painful for Hélène.
Borís and Anna Pávlovna returned to the others.
Prince Hippolyte had the ear of the company.
Prince Hippolyte said "Le Roi de Prusse!" while bending forward in his armchair.
Prince Hippolyte laughed after saying "Le Roi de Prusse!".
Everyone turned toward Prince Hippolyte.
Prince Hippolyte said "Le Roi de Prusse?" again, interrogatively, while laughing.
Prince Hippolyte calmly and seriously sat back in his chair after saying "Le Roi de Prusse?".
Anna Pávlovna waited for Prince Hippolyte to continue speaking.
Prince Hippolyte seemed decided to say no more.
Anna Pávlovna began to tell of how at Potsdam the impious Bonaparte had stolen the sword of Frederick the Great.
Anna Pávlovna began to say "It is the sword of Frederick the Great which I...".
Prince Hippolyte interrupted Anna Pávlovna with "Le Roi de Prusse...".
Prince Hippolyte excused himself and said no more.
Anna Pávlovna frowned.
Mortemart addressed Prince Hippolyte firmly.
Mortemart said "Come now, what about your Roi de Prusse?".
Prince Hippolyte laughed as if ashamed of laughing.
Prince Hippolyte said "Oh, it’s nothing. I only wished to say...".
Prince Hippolyte wanted to repeat a joke he had heard in Vienna.
Prince Hippolyte had been trying all that evening to get the joke in.
Prince Hippolyte said "I only wished to say that we are wrong to fight pour le Roi de Prusse!".
Borís smiled circumspectly.
Borís smiled so that it might be taken as ironical or appreciative.
Everybody laughed.
Anna Pávlovna said "Your joke is too bad, it’s witty but unjust."
Anna Pávlovna shook her little shriveled finger at Prince Hippolyte.
Anna Pávlovna said "We are not fighting pour le Roi de Prusse, but for right principles."
Anna Pávlovna said "Oh, that wicked Prince Hippolyte!"
The conversation did not flag all evening.
The conversation turned chiefly on the political news.
The conversation became particularly animated toward the end of the evening.
Rewards bestowed by the Emperor were mentioned.
"The man of profound intellect" said "You know N— N— received a snuffbox with the portrait last year?"
"The man of profound intellect" asked "Why shouldn’t S— S— get the same distinction?"
The diplomatist said "Pardon me! A snuffbox with the Emperor’s portrait is a reward but not a distinction."
The diplomatist said "It is a gift, rather."
Someone said "There are precedents, I may mention Schwarzenberg."
Another replied "It’s impossible."
Someone said "Will you bet? The ribbon of the order is a different matter."
Hélène turned to Borís.
Hélène asked Borís in a tone of caressing significant command to come to her on Tuesday.
Hélène said "It is of great importance to me."
Hélène turned with a smile toward Anna Pávlovna.
Anna Pávlovna supported Hélène’s wish with the same sad smile with which she spoke of her exalted patroness.
It seemed as if from some words Borís had spoken that evening about the Prussian army, Hélène had suddenly found it necessary to see him.
Hélène seemed to promise to explain that necessity to him when he came on Tuesday.
Borís came to Hélène’s splendid salon on Tuesday evening.
Borís received no clear explanation of why it had been necessary for him to come.
There were other guests in Hélène’s salon.
The countess talked little to Borís.
Borís kissed Hélène's hand on taking leave.
Borís said unexpectedly and in a whisper, with a strangely unsmiling face: "Come to dinner tomorrow... in the evening. You must come.... Come!"
During that stay in Petersburg, Borís became an intimate in the countess’ house.
